resources.string: When short vowels are paired with dead endings, there are some spelling transformations, which include some new symbols. The tone rules for short vowels and dead endings are the same as for syllables with short vowels and no endings. As a result, while learning this topic you can rely on knowledge you have already gained, and you can reinforce that earlier knowledge when working on this topic.

Three of the short vowels have spelling transformations when they occur in syllables with dead endings. The transformations include things like substituting a new symbol, dropping symbols, and so on. The transformations of a given vowel are the same for each of the three dead endings, so it’s sufficient to illustrate them with random syllables ending in ก, for example.

When you encounter a new word or syllable consisting of a consonant, a long vowel, and a dead ending, if you prefer the mnemonic, you don’t have to remember the tone rule explicitly. Instead, ask yourself, is the syllable like เด็ก or เล็ก or นับ or สิบ ? In other words, you’re asking yourself whether the initial consonant is mid, high, or low. If you can “feel” the class of the consonant, then you apply the tone from the syllable in the mnemonic device which “feels” like it.
